I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  proposed  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the 
Government of Mongolia in preparing a health sector master plan (HSMP) for 2019–2027. The 
proposed TA will provide institutional and human resource capacity to the Ministry of Health (MOH) 
to develop a strategic framework through 2027. This will enable the MOH to pursue its long-term 
development policy on health in accordance with Mongolia’s commitments to health-related 
targets under the Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030 (SDV 2030).1 
 
2.  The TA is included in the country operations business plan, 2017–2019 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for Mongolia and is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 
2017–2020 for Mongolia, which emphasizes social development through the efficient delivery of 
health services under the strategy’s health and social protection focus.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In the 1990s, Mongolia implemented reforms that successfully transformed its former 
Soviet-style hospital-based approach into a more efficient people-oriented health care system. 
Challenges persist, however, including improving sector efficiency and health service delivery, 
quality, availability, and accessibility; increasing financial support and protection for the people; 
and improving sector governance. Achieving these targets requires close coordination between 
government agencies and a well-planned sequencing of reforms. As the Health Sector Strategic 
Master Plan (HSSMP), 2005–20153 has expired, developing a new master plan is essential to 
ensure that government targets are achieved and hard-won gains in key health indicators, such 
as the improvements achieved in maternal and infant mortality, are sustained. The HSMP will 
build on the 2017 State Policy on Health, which defines the core principles and development goals 
for the health sector for 2017–2026.4 The overarching goals of the government objectives are to 
(i) extend life expectancy by improving the quality and inclusiveness of health care services 
through the introduction of reliable technology in prevention, diagnostics, and treatment; and 
(ii) develop  an  adequate  health  care  financing  system  and  good  sector  governance  amid 
economic difficulty and fiscal budget constraints. The HSMP, which will align closely with the SDV 
2030 health targets, is instrumental to achieving these goals. 
 
4.  Widespread staff turnover at the MOH since 2012 because of political instability has 
resulted in capacity constraints, leading to the suspension or interruption of several policy 
initiatives. Lack of handover mechanisms and regular professional training compounds the 
situation. Some 90 MOH staff and 380 staff in 23 provincial health departments involved in policy 
planning and coordination need training. This prevents the MOH from assessing the impact and 
pitfalls of the reforms implemented since 1990s, which hampers evidence-based decision-making 
on health sector reforms and strategies. Addressing capacity constraints is essential to ensure 
the effective implementation of the government’s policy actions and better coordination and 
integration of internal and external resources in the health sector. 
 
                                                
1  The State Great Khural of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 July 2017. ADB. 2017. Country 
Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of Economic Difficulty. Manila; 
and ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 2017–2019. Manila. 
3  Government of Mongolia, MOH. 2005. Health Sector Strategic Master Plan, 2006–2015. Ulaanbaatar. Development 
of the HSSMP was financially supported by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan at the request of the 
Government of Mongolia in 2003. 
4  Government of Mongolia. 2017. State Policy on Health 2017–2026. Decree No. 17. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
5.  Since 1997, ADB has been the leading development partner for the Government of 
Mongolia and the MOH to reform the country’s health care system. ADB has contributed to (i) 
reforming the health service delivery system by developing a primary health care and referral 
system and introducing a public–private partnership concept in service delivery, (ii) rationalizing 
hospital services and improving hospital management and governance, (iii) improving sector 
governance  by  introducing  licensing  and  accreditation  systems  and  information  and 
communication technology systems for health statistics and reporting, and (iv) reforming the 
health care financing system by introducing new payment methods and output-based budgeting 
principles. The government has requested ADB’s support in preparing the HSMP to ensure the 
effective development and implementation of sector targets, which will include capacity building 
for effective sector-wide management at the MOH. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) access to and quality of preventive, 
diagnostic, and medical services improved; and (ii) government strategic programming, health 
care policy development, and planning enhanced.5 The TA will have the following outcome: health 
sector midterm strategic framework developed.6 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Health sector master plan, 2019–2027 developed. This output will focus on 
developing the HSMP, 2019–2027. The development process will (i) assess the previous HSSMP 
to identify the achievements and lessons learned; (ii) assess the major health sector reforms 
undertaken since 1990s; (iii) review situational analysis documents to define the core strategic 
areas and build on State Policy on Health priorities and SDV 2030 objectives and targets; (iv) 
develop strategies in core priority areas; and (v) draft a master plan and its supporting documents, 
including a midterm expenditure framework and financial and investment plans. 
 
8.  The TA will establish a stakeholders’ consultation and coordination mechanism at the 
MOH to ensure the participation of all stakeholders, a sector-wide approach, and ownership of 
the development of the HSMP. The TA will publish the HSMP and its supporting documents, such 
as (i) the midterm investment framework, (ii) the planning and budgeting framework, (iii) the 
midterm expenditure framework, (iv) the monitoring and evaluation framework, and (v) the 
implementation framework, in digital and print formats and in Mongolian and English. The print 
documents will serve as reference documents for government staff and decision makers at all 
levels, including rural soums (districts) and aimags (provinces) with limited or no access to internet, 
nongovernment agencies, international partners, academia, and research institutions involved in 
health care service delivery, planning, and implementation. 
 
9.  Output 2: Planning, monitoring, and coordination capacity of the Ministry of Health 
strengthened. This output will focus on institutional capacity building to strengthen the planning 
and coordination functions and the technical skills of staff at the MOH and local government 
agencies through a learning-by-doing approach. TA consultants will work in partnership with 
government officials through the technical working groups that will be established to deliver 
                                                
5  The State Great Khural of Mongolia. 2016. Action Program of the Government of Mongolia for 2016–2020. Annex to 
Resolution 45 of 2016 of the State Great Khural of Mongolia. Ulaanbaatar. 
6  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
specific deliverables under output 1. In addition, output 2 will include formal and on-the-job training 
for government officials using competency-based task analysis. Emphasis will be given to health 
care planning, financial planning, impact assessment of health interventions, health technology 
assessment, health needs assessment, investment or capital planning, monitoring and evaluation 
of health programs, and development partner and aid coordination in the sector. 
 
10.  The TA  will  use  a  wide  participatory  and  consultative  approach  where  the  primary 
responsibility lies at the MOH while ensuring (i) participation and engagement of national and 
international stakeholders from the onset; (ii) broad and systematic consultation with health sector 
stakeholders,  including  medical  staff,  clients,  professional  associations,  and  private  sector 
participants; (iii) use of an evidence-based approach and a well-documented strategy; and 
(iv) promotion of ownership at the central and local levels through dissemination of the strategy 
documents for discussion and feedback. The TA will support the government’s review and 
assessment of previous and ongoing health sector reforms by engaging all key stakeholders in 
their domains and areas of expertise. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,080,000, of which $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation for 
the project implementation unit and consultants, venue for meetings, access to data, and other 
in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented from November 2017 to November 2019. The MOH will be 
the executing agency, and its Health Policy and Planning Department will be the implementing 
agency. ADB will administer the TA. 
 
14.  Disbursement of the TA proceeds will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). To facilitate implementation, ADB will establish 
an advance payment facility for the executing agency to support certain agreed cash expenditures 
for the organization of training, seminars, and conferences; and project administration. The 
executing agency will submit details of the proposed activities and cost estimates to ADB for prior 
approval. ADB will also make certain direct payments. 
 
15.  The executing agency will purchase office equipment and procure goods for printing and 
publishing following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time). TA 
project implementation unit will transfer office equipment to the executing agency upon completion 
of TA activities. 
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm following ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time).7 The selected firm will provide 
73 person-months of consulting services in health care and financial planning, health needs and 
technology assessment, and capacity building. ADB will recruit the firm through the quality- and 
cost-based selection procedure (quality–cost ratio of 90:10) and engage it using a performance-
                                                
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

4 
based contract. ADB will also engage a project coordinator for 24 person-months and an 
administrative and finance coordinator for 24 person-months. The two project coordinators will be 
responsible  for  the  TA’s  day-to-day  activities  and  will  be  recruited  by  ADB  as  individual 
consultants following the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.

17.  ADB will evaluate the TA process during its review missions based on the performance 
targets and indicators defined in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for the Development of the Health Sector Master Plan, 2019–2027; and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

6  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  HSMP, 2019–2027 developed 
1.1  Establish thematic and technical working groups, define working procedures, and prepare a road 
map for the development of the HSMP (Q1 2018) 
1.2  Develop the stakeholders’ engagement and consultation mechanism and plan (Q2 2018) 
1.3  Conduct a rapid performance assessment of the Health Sector Strategic Master Plan, 2005–2015; 
and identify key achievements, challenges, and lessons learned (Q1–Q3 2018) 
1.4  Review and assess the major health sector reforms undertaken since 1990s (Q2–Q4 2018) 
1.5  Review and analyze health sector situational analysis documents and define the core strategies in 
the priority areas (Q2–Q4 2018) 
1.6  Develop a draft HSMP and finalize it in consultation with the stakeholders (Q4 2018–Q3 2019) 
1.7  Develop the HSMP supporting documents, including the midterm planning and budgeting, 
investment, expenditure, and monitoring and evaluation frameworks (Q4 2018–Q3 2019) 
1.8  Hold regional and national conferences to consult with the stakeholders; and to present, discuss, and 
obtain feedback on the working documents and the HSMP (2018–2019) 
 
2.  Planning, monitoring, and coordination capacity of the MOH strengthened 
2.1  Conduct training needs assessment to undertake institutional and human resource development to 
strengthen the planning, monitoring, and coordination capacity of the MOH and city and aimag 
(provincial) health departments (Q2 2018) 
2.2  Develop an institutional and human resource capacity-building program focusing on health impact, 
health technology and health needs assessments, capital planning, and monitoring and evaluation of 
health programs (Q3 2018) 
2.3  Implement the training and capacity-building program (2018–2019)
